Comment: Oof. Congress has never taken money out of Social Security - this is a profound misunderstanding.  You’re correct that SS is self-financed through dedicated payroll taxes and trust fund assets, but you’re incorrect that this avoids budget or deficit impacts.  When SS runs a cash flow deficit (as it does, by some $200B this year), they have to redeem trust fund bonds and that actual cash has to be found somewhere (general revenue, cost-cutting, more borrowing).  In a more indirect sense, the cost of SS is relevant even if it weren’t running a cash flow deficit. If the total value of SS taxes weren’t required to pay for SS, they could be spent elsewhere. We can’t just say “SS pays for itself so it’s fine” - we need to evaluate “we are collecting $1.3T in taxes for this program that we could be spending elsewhere if this program weren’t so expensive”.

Comment: Nobody has “paid in” to the system or is “owed” anything. Current taxpayers are paying benefits to current enrollees - there is a common misconception that people are just drawing down what they paid in.   It’s a fallacy - the taxes retirees paid have already been spent.   When we think about the economic environment for younger people today and the fact that increasing amounts of incomes will need to be dedicated to paying social security checks to a generation holding a huge share of expensive real estate, many with pensions, many with 401ks and IRAs in the millions of dollars, it opens up a massive window for a reconsideration of the SS “contract”.  Now, I wouldn’t personally support any proposal that removed Social Security from anyone currently receiving it right away. Even for means-testing, I’d recommend tapering off benefits over time. And for those who clearly need Social Security - if you’re above, at, or near retirement age, you shouldn’t have to worry about the system being changed on you all of a sudden.   But we have to start thinking about the future because this is a future-oriented program. If we’re eventually going to rely on market solutions, the time to start those investments is now. If we keep blindly defending the status quo because we’re afraid to rock the boat, we aren’t taking governance seriously.
